text: we often hear about a company
particularly tech firms in Silicon
Valley being valued at billions of
dollars but even some of the really
really popular ones don't make any
profits yep seriously like literally not
a penny nope it's totally normal but
most companies lose money when they
start out even the really big ones
[Music]
all depends on what people are prepared
to pay for shares if lots of people
think the company is going to be really
successful then more people try and buy
those shares so the price for each share
goes up and as shares get more expensive
the valuation of the whole company goes
up to the whole system got completely
out of whack during the dot-com bubble
years before then you had to be making a
profit to have a high valuation but from
the mid 90s hundreds of companies making
no profits launched on the stock market
some of them went bust but some of them
made billions maybe you and me without
even knowing our pension funds put money
in all kinds of companies on the stock
market they're going to hang on to those
shares for years and hope that
eventually they get a steady stream of
cash to pay for our pensions but some
investors are in it for a quick
turnaround they're holding on to shares
that everyone wants and selling them on
quickly for a profit of course
[Music]
nope because they're always tasting the
end of the rainbow to find the next big
thing when a company's planning to turn
an industry upside down or do something
totally new the possibilities can be
pretty massive
it certainly doesn't happen every time
and when companies don't grow as quickly
as they'd hoped and the prospects of
those future profits starts to fade into
the distance
investors will lose patience they'll
sell the shares and the value of the
company tanks that even happens to
companies as big as Facebook to make big
money you've got to get in there early
with your cash hoping the company is a
fantastic success it's a gamble though
because plenty of companies promise you
the moon but don't even get off the
